doc.field: Sentence against Pastor Geyer announced

The murder sentence against Pastor Klaus Geyer was continued in the morning at the Regional Court in Braunschweig. Geyer is accused of slaying his wife in the heat of passion. The 20th day of trial began with two dead ants. One ant was found on the dead body of Veronika Geyer and the other one was found under a dirty boot the police seized in Geyer's vehicle. Several experts agreed that the dirt came with great likelihood from the scene of the crime. A comparison of the two ants is supposed to reveal whether the two animals are alike and could be from the crime scene. Delays in the trial are expected if the experts cannot come to a clear result.
Construction industry: agreement in sight

A wage agreement is likely to occur soon in the construction industry. Employers and unions continued negotiations in Mainz with intentions to reach an agreement by the end of the day. It is unknown what the agreement will look like. A small-percentage wage increase is likely and some sort of compensation which was requested by the employers. A break down is unlikely but cannot be ruled out.
Energy tax: industry fears elimination of jobs

Henkel fears the elimination of jobs due to the energy tax. The President of the Federation of the German Industry rejects the introduction of so-called energy taxes to make energy more expensive. It would lead to higher unemployment and prevent investment. A reduction of carbon dioxide emissions could not be guaranteed with such a tax. The Bavarian State Premier Stoiber called the discussions about the energy tax unrealistic and rejected increased costs of energy on a national level.
State employees are sick more often

The Institute of German Economy presented a new study about absence from the work place. According to the study, employees in the Public Sector are sick more often and for longer periods of time. On the average, each state employee misses four weeks of work per year due to sickness. Insurance and bank employees are absent less often, with an average of nine days per year.
Honouring Berlin Airlift

With ceremonies in Berlin, German politicians honoured the American General Lucius Clay. Clay died 20 years ago and is known as the organizer of the airlift. The Mayor of Berlin Diepgen said at ceremonies at the Tempelhof airport that Clay saved the people from death from starvation and secured freedom and democracy in Berlin. In 1948, Berlin was blocked off by the Soviets under Stalin, and the only supply lines were the three air corridors of the Allied forces. In the first untertaking of its kind, groceries and supplies were flown in from the Western regions. Supplies were dropped off on nearly 300,000 flights from planes referred to as "Rosinenbomber" (Raisin Bombers).
Lower taxes announced

Today the CDU announced its plans for the economy. While Mr Schaeuble had mentioned the introduction of energy taxes in his thesis papers, the Economic Speaker of the CDU Wissmann made it clear today that taxes will be lowered after a victory.
Rexrodt welcomes lower phone fees

According to Federal Economics Minister Guenter Rexrodt opening the telecommunication market for competition is a success. After 100 days of open markets prices dropped already. Nearly 50 suppliers are negotiating business deals which in the past could only be offered by the German Telekom. Rexrodt expects further price reductions. Prices for long-distance calls dropped already by up to 70% throughout the country. For one-minute phone calls during the day the rate is currently between 19 and 60 cents.
Stamm plans reductions

Bavaria is planning to decrease benefits for social welfare recipients if they are not willing to contribute work to society. People who have time and physical strength to work should feel obligated to solidarity.
Millions for busses and subways

Local public transportation in Bavaria is subsidized with DM 260 million. The Ministry of Transport in Munich announced plans to extend the subway network and establish park-and-ride sites. The goal is for busses and subways to take on the majority of traffic increases.
Kidnappers demanding ransom
The kidnappers of the ten Red Cross workers in Somalia demanded a ransom of DM 1.8 million. A German citizen is among the workers who were kidnapped at the airstrip north of Mogadishu.
